The uniform magnetic field B is parallel to OO′ (i.e. along the rotation axis).

Every element of the rod moves in a plane perpendicular to B; the motional-emf generated between the axis (point O) and the sliding end M is the same as that of a 'rotating conductor rod' in a uniform axial field.
For a rod of length r that rotates with angular speed ω in a field B parallel to the axis, the induced emf between its ends is E = ½ B ω r².
The factor ½ comes from integrating v × B ∙ dl along the rod: v = ω r′, dl = dr′.
Initial situation: Magnetic field magnitude is B₀, angular speed is ω₀, voltmeter reading is U₀.
From the formula E = ½ B ω r², U₀ = ½ B₀ ω₀ r².
New situation: Magnetic field magnitude is changed to n B₀, and we want the voltmeter to read m U₀.
Using the formula E = ½ B ω r² again, m U₀ = ½ (n B₀) ω r².
Insert U₀ from Eq. (2) into Eq. (3): m (½ B₀ ω₀ r²) = ½ (n B₀) ω r².
Cancel the common factors ½ B₀ r², resulting in m ω₀ = n ω.
Solve for ω: ω = (m / n) ω₀.
To make the voltmeter read m U₀ in a magnetic field n B₀, the shaft must rotate with angular velocity ω = (m / n) ω₀.
